docs.lead_paragraph: A hard-fought measure to legalize physician-assisted suicide in California cleared the state Assembly on Wednesday despite opposition from religious groups and advocates for the disabled, and moved to the state Senate, where it was widely expected to gain final passage.

headline.main: Assisted-Suicide Bill Approved by California Assembly
headline.print_headline: Assisted-Suicide Bill Approved by California Assembly

docs.lead_paragraph: Illinois' pile of unpaid bills is on track to top $8.5 billion by year-end as payments mandated by state law or courts in the absence of an enacted budget exceed available revenue, the state comptroller said on Wednesday.

headline.main: Illinois' Unpaid Bill Pile Grows as Budget Battle Drags On
headline.print_headline: Illinois' Unpaid Bill Pile Grows as Budget Battle Drags On

docs.snippet: Illinois' pile of unpaid bills is on track to top $8.5 billion by year-end as payments mandated by state law or courts in the absence of an enacted budget exceed available revenue, the state comptroller said on Wednesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: The family doctor visit is getting complicated. Drugstores and other retailers are opening clinics that offer care alternatives. Shrinking insurance has made routine visits to a physician more expensive for many. Here are three tips for navigating this evolving world:

headline.main: 3 Tips for Adjusting to Changes in Primary Health Care

docs.lead_paragraph: United Airlines abruptly replaced its CEO as a federal investigation continued into whether the airline gave preferential treatment to a former chairman of the agency that operates the New York-area airports who has political ties to New Jersey Gov. and presidential candidate Chris Christie.

headline.main: United CEO Jeff Smisek Steps Down Amid Federal Investigation

docs.lead_paragraph: Australia and Switzerland have found ways to avoid ridiculously high prices while still protecting profits and incentives.
docs.abstract: Ezekiel J Emanuel Op-Ed article claims price of prescription drugs, which can cost individual several hundred thousand dollars per year, is excessive; argues proposals like using Medicare to negotiate lower prices would drive up costs for those privately insured; proposes United States look to Switzerland and Australia as models for offering effective drugs cheaply, as what concerns patients most is getting good results at reasonable cost.
docs.snippet: Australia and Switzerland have found ways to avoid ridiculously high prices while still protecting profits and incentives.

docs.lead_paragraph: A report from the Institute for Clinical and Economic Review says the prices on two drugs to fight cholesterol that cost more than $14,000 a year should be slashed.

headline.main: New Cholesterol Drugs Are Vastly Overpriced, Analysis Says
headline.print_headline: New Cholesterol Drugs Are Overpriced, Analysis Finds

docs.abstract: Institute for Clinical and Economic Review finds cholesterol-lowering drugs Repatha and Praluent are very overpriced given value they offer; report, which is used by health plans in price negotiations, could force drug makers Amgen and Sanofi to offer larger discounts.
docs.snippet: A report from the Institute for Clinical and Economic Review says the prices on two drugs to fight cholesterol that cost more than $14,000 a year should be slashed.

keywords.value: Institute for Clinical and Economic Review
keywords.name: organizations
